title: Netanyahu’s Alliance With Trump Tests Israel’s Bond with U.S. Jews
text:
JERUSALEM—Highways all over Israel are plastered these days with election billboards showing a grinning Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu shaking hands with President Trump.

Mr. Netanyahu is looking to capitalize on this relationship ahead of the Sept. 17 vote. Moving the U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem and backing Israeli sovereignty over the annexed Golan Heights have made Mr. Trump widely popular among Israeli Jews, with 79% in a recent survey by the American Jewish Committee approving of his handling of relations with Israel.

On Saturday, Mr. Trump went a step further and said he would work toward a mutual defense treaty with Israel. Mr. Netanyahu warmly embraced the idea, even though both countries have discussed and rejected it in the past, with Israel saying it didn’t want its actions constrained.

The bond between Messrs. Netanyahu and Trump, however, also potentially deepens the rift between Israel and millions of American Jews, a predominantly liberal community where 36% approve of Mr. Trump’s handling of U.S.-Israel relations and 26% endorse the president’s overall performance, according to the survey.

Schism American and Israeli Jews are divided on a number of political issues. American 64% 26 10 Israeli 39% 51 9 Do you support or oppose the recent American recognition of the Golan Heights as Israeli territory? American 50% 39 11 88% 5 7 Israeli

Several American Jewish organizations have condemned Mr. Trump’s recent remarks that Jews voting for the Democratic Party show great disloyalty, saying these were the latest in a pattern of statements that revive anti-Semitic tropes.

The problem for Israel is that this anger with Mr. Trump’s policies and political style have increasingly fueled disenchantment with the Jewish state itself—a process that weakens support from a crucial community and frays the historically bipartisan nature of the U.S.-Israeli relationship.

“While the Israeli government appears to be President Trump’s greatest fan, American Jewry is sometimes horrified by his words and actions,” said Itzik Shmuli, a lawmaker from Israel’s left-wing Labor Party. “The clear effort of President Trump and Prime Minister Netanyahu to turn Israel literally into a local branch of the Republican Party—and at a clear cost of an ever-growing detachment between Israel and the Democrats—is a harmful and serious trend.”

Some Democratic politicians have embraced the so-called BDS campaign to boycott, divest and sanction Israel for its treatment of Palestinians, as have a handful of left-wing American Jewish organizations, such as the Jewish Voice for Peace. The group’s co-director, Rabbi Alissa Wise, described Israel earlier this month as “the greatest obstacle to peace in the Middle East.” Though such opinions remain a minority view, they are a sign of alienation between American Jews and Israel.

A split between Israel and American Jews, should it solidify, “would be a very big tragedy for the Jewish people,” said Jerusalem Rabbi Michael Melchior, who served as minister of diaspora affairs in a center-left government in 1999-2001.

According to a Pew Research poll conducted in April, some 42% of American Jews now believe that Mr. Trump favors Israel too much, compared with 15% among evangelicals, and 26% among all U.S. Christians.

Mr. Trump visited Jerusalem in 2017. Mr. Netanyahu has sought to draw support from voters’ approval of Mr. Trump’s Israel policies. Photo: ronen zvulun/Reuters

Mr. Netanyahu’s supporters in Israel argue that Mr. Trump’s policies are the only ones that will lead to true peace, pointing to the failure of previous negotiations with Palestinians. “He has fulfilled his campaign promises, unlike many of his predecessors, and he has come out very boldly focusing on the truth the way we see it,” said Nir Barkat, a senior lawmaker in Mr. Netanyahu’s Likud party who was mayor of Jerusalem from 2008 to 2018.

The drifting apart of Israel and American Jews can’t really be halted, though it can be mitigated, added Michael Oren, who served as Israel’s ambassador to Washington and, until earlier this year, as deputy minister in Mr. Netanyahu’s office. “These are historical processes that are beyond our control,” he said.

The split stems from the opposing visions of Israel as a beleaguered nation-state in a rough neighborhood and of American Jews as part of a pluralistic society, said Mr. Oren, a native of New York state.

“The American Jewish idea is fundamentally different from the Jewish Zionist idea. The American Jewish idea is that Judaism is a universal religion, that we are not a nation or a people, that our duty is to all of humanity, and that America is the promised land, and that the Land of Israel is not the promised land,” he said.

That fundamental gap, he added, has prompted many Israeli right-wing politicians to essentially give up on liberal American Jews and focus on friendlier constituencies such as evangelicals.

A religious schism reinforces these differences. Conservative and Reform streams of Judaism that are practiced by most American Jews aren’t legally recognized in Israel, where the Orthodox establishment dominates religious matters and Mr. Netanyahu relies on the support of ultra-Orthodox political parties.

Mr. Netanyahu unveiled a new Jewish settlement in the Golan Heights named after President Trump in June, after Mr. Trump in March recognized Israel’s sovereignty there. Photo: jalaa marey/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images

American Orthodox and ultra-Orthodox Jews, unlike much of the rest of the community, are mostly supportive of Mr. Trump, according to surveys.

“The extremely important divide is not between diaspora and Israel, it is between liberal Jews and conservative Jews,” said Yoram Hazony, president of the Herzl Institute in Jerusalem and author of a recent book praising the virtues of nationalism that has been popular within the Trump administration.

“The liberal Jews are committed to a certain set of universal ideas, and these ideas are strongly in tension not only with Jewish nationalism, but also with Orthodox Judaism, and in general with Jewish traditions,” he said.

The political disconnect between American Jews and Israel goes deeper. American Jews are well to the left of the Israeli left-wing on many issues, and Aipac, the most prominent American pro-Israel lobbying organization, is finding itself to the left of Mr. Netanyahu’s current policies.

Aipac still supports a two-state solution in the Palestinian conflict, despite Mr. Netanyahu’s promises to annex West Bank land and prevent the establishment of a Palestinian state. It has also criticized the Israeli leader’s August decision—which followed a request by Mr. Trump—to bar a visit by Democratic Congress members Rashida Tlaib and Ilhan Omar because of their support for the BDS movement.

Mr. Trump’s embassy move was another such marker. It was welcomed across Israel’s Jewish political spectrum, including by left-wing politicians such as Mr. Shmuli. Only 7% of Israeli Jews opposed the decision.

Yet, more American Jews disapproved than approved of it, according to last year’s survey by AJC.

“It’s a historic challenge we are facing: Growing apart is something extremely disturbing,” said Isaac Herzog, executive chairman of the Jewish Agency, an Israeli quasi-government body in charge of Jewish immigration and ties with the diaspora.

A completely different life experience is part of the reason, he said in an interview in Tel Aviv.

“My kids that grew up here—they would sing ‘Give Peace a Chance’ but they know they have to serve in the army. A young North American Jew can opt whether to be Jewish or not,” said Mr. Herzog, who unsuccessfully challenged Mr. Netanyahu for prime minister as the center-left’s candidate in the 2015 elections. “My son could be on the border of Gaza trying to block 50,000 Palestinians with hand grenades and knives, and his parallel on campus somewhere in North America may look at him as the villain in the conflict.”

Write to Yaroslav Trofimov at yaroslav.trofimov@wsj.com
description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is looking to capitalize on his alliance with President Trump in an election on Tuesday, but the relationship has a flip side: it deepens a rift between Israeli and American Jews.
